metadata.title: Management Consulting Vs Strategy Consulting (Differences Explained)
metadata.author: My Consulting Offer

key_facts: Strategy consulting focuses on the 'what' question in business: what to do.
Management consulting addresses both the 'what' and the 'how' of business operations.
All strategy consultants are management consultants, but not all management consultants are strategy consultants.
Strategy consultants typically work with C-suite executives such as CEOs and CFOs.
Non-strategy management consultants usually work with VPs, directors, and division heads.
A strategy consultant might recommend launching a product in Thailand based on market analysis.
After strategy is set, non-strategy management consultants handle implementation details like supply chain and sales.
Management consultants can specialize in areas such as supply chain, sales, or risk assessment.
Strategy consultants at firms like McKinsey, Bain, and BCG work 50–60 hours per week on average.
Non-strategy management consultants typically work 45–55 hours per week on average.
Work hours in consulting vary based on project type, timeline, and client demands.
Projects with no prior templates require more on-the-job learning and increase workload.
Shorter timelines (e.g., six days vs. six months) lead to higher intensity and longer hours.
Clients requiring on-site presence or frequent after-hours communication extend working hours.
Some management consultants earn more than strategy consultants due to rare expertise.
Highly specialized knowledge in niche fields allows management consultants to command higher fees.
Management consultants in high-stakes industries like offshore oil drilling can charge more due to risk exposure.
Incorrect safety or compliance advice in oil projects could result in fatalities and massive financial loss.
Former strategy consultants have served as CEOs of Google and Starbucks.
Startups often rely on management consultants for operational execution rather than strategic planning.
Operational experience from non-strategy management consulting is valuable in early-stage companies.
Strategy consultants gain exposure to multiple industries, functions, and verticals during their careers.
Exposure to diverse industries helps consultants identify personal interests and career preferences.
A strategy consulting background provides transferable skills even if transitioning into operational roles.
The speaker has helped over 600 people land consulting jobs through their program.
key_opinions: Strategy consulting is better for those aiming to become CEO or president of a large company.
Non-strategy management consulting is suitable for individuals who want to stay in operations or start a company.
If you don’t know your future goals, strategy consulting offers broader exposure to help decide.
Strategy consulting provides better long-term career flexibility and decision-making clarity.
Management consultants with rare expertise can earn more than strategy consultants despite average pay differences.
High-risk projects justify higher compensation for management consultants due to potential consequences.
Work-life balance is generally better for non-strategy management consultants compared to strategy consultants.
The choice between roles should be guided by post-consulting career aspirations.
Exposure to C-suite leaders during strategy consulting builds leadership readiness.
Early-stage startups benefit more from operational experience than strategic direction.
Strategy consultants may lack hands-on implementation experience compared to their management counterparts.
Seeing multiple industries helps consultants develop clearer career direction.
Staying in consulting long-term is easier with a strategy consulting background due to versatility.
The speaker’s program has a strong track record of success with an 89.6% offer rate.
Free strategy sessions are recommended to map out individual career paths effectively.
key_datapoints: Strategy consultants earn 20–30% more than non-strategy management consultants on average.
Average weekly hours for strategy consultants at top firms: 50–60 hours.
Average weekly hours for non-strategy management consultants: 45–55 hours.
Over 600 people have been helped by the speaker’s team to land consulting jobs.
The program has an 89.6% success rate: 9 out of every 10 participants receive at least one offer.
Dwayne Johnson’s tequila brand, Terematta, operates in exactly 150 countries.
The speaker recommends strategy consulting for those targeting executive leadership roles.
Google and Starbucks both had former strategy consultants as their current CEOs.
One example project involved recommending Thailand as the next market launch location.
Oil industry consultants specializing in HR, compliance, and safety command premium rates.
Only four specialists worldwide may know about certain rare medical conditions.
Consultants with rare expertise can charge more due to limited availability.
Projects with no prior templates require more time and learning effort.
Client calls at 2 a.m. extend working hours beyond standard schedules.
Travel to client sites adds significant time due to airport transit and flight duration.

I'd push, you know, that on the government level when we're talking about societies,

percent of, I don't know what your numbers are, I have my limit there, they

within organizations. And then of course, within
countries and society. And I'd add one more layer onto that,
which is an old problem, but a thing that I think is new, you know, in,
in the past when we had much more hierarchical organizations, right. There was a human development. portion that came along with the HR
systems, which is, you know, when you first got promoted to be this level,
you got enrolled in this program and you had a cohort all across your company. And then as you moved sort of up the
organization, there was training at every level and you had your support network. And I see all of that just. Fraying in so many companies. And to me, the, the thing that just
symbolizes the end of that era was when General Electric very quietly
sold off their Crotonville facility. I mean, this would have been
unthinkable even 25 years ago. And so what's happening is now
that the demands on leaders and managers have been vastly increased. The complexity they're dealing with is

Stanford great intellectual experience? change doesn't happen that way. So I think this shift understanding
training doesn't help. I mean, Steve Blank famously says when
your innovation department has become your training department, you're doomed. So I think that the ability to experiment
a lot more with new things and AI and gen AI is a big one now, but that goes for any

training because it doesn't create change. Towards a real process of experimentation
and change to embrace that because that's how the solutions are going to emerge. That's how you get people to
change by actually doing real work. Do they need to learn in the process? You bet. It's not focused on learning. It's focused on the outcome
and you get the outcome by experimenting with these new trends. And if you don't
experiment, you can't learn. So it's not short
learning is not the goal. The goal is outcomes and change. So I think we just need to
shift more towards trying stuff. Analysis is not going to solve
anything when it comes to the new, the new stuff can be overthought. You're still not going to decrease risk. The only thing is trying out and starting,
and that's the entrepreneurial discipline. So a lot more companies are going to
have to become more entrepreneurial and do stuff, try stuff. where they don't know if it's
going to work, but that's how they figure out what works. Yeah, and from my side, I would say
I talk about strategic inflection points as something that's a shift
in the environment that makes a 10x shift in what's possible happen. So about 10 times faster,
cheaper, smarter, whatever. And we're right on the brink of
a major inflection point in how organizations need to be organized. if you think about most of our,
especially larger organizations, they're still really organized around
a hypothesis about bureaucracy. And we've forgotten now, you know,
bureaucracy has kind of become a swear word almost, but we forget
that when bureaucracy was first invented, it was an improvement to
the previous state of affairs, which was really craftsmen and guilds. And there wasn't a lot of consistency
and bureaucracy was an attempt to impose some science on that. But now we're getting to a stage
where, for example, take silos. right? The reason silos work in a bureaucracy
is you take all the people who are doing similar work and you clump
them all together in one unit. Well, today that's not necessary anymore. And as AI has made all those
functional skills readily available to anybody, we need a different
center of gravity for organizing. And I think that's something people have
not really understood the implications of. So I'll give you a you
know, an everyday example. I work with a lot of companies and
pharmaceuticals and banking and stuff. And for many, many years, everybody's
career was defined by how far up the hierarchy you went, right? So if I got promoted, it
was to the next level. And now when you've got hierarchies
flattening and people, you know, whose value is really determined by
what their areas of responsibility are, rather than by what hierarchical
title they hold, there's a completely different career logic happening. And I don't think many people
are ready for that yet. lots lots of food for thought guys i
am so grateful to you so i'm gonna come around and say ryan shanks head of. innovation for Accenture for EMEA
alexander Osterwalder ceo Strategyzer Columbia professor and author reid
mcgrath thank you all for joining us. Thank you thank you

metadata.title: Will AI Replace Consultants - Reality of Management Consulting in 2024 | MBB | McKinsey BCG Bain
metadata.author: Pavan Sathiraju

key_facts: McKinsey, BCG, and Bain saw revenue increases in 2021 and 2022.
These consulting firms faced a reality check in 2023.
Unlike big tech companies, they lack leverage from the AI boom.
AI could pose a risk to consulting firms if it continues to grow.
Specialized niche consulting firms focus on one domain like mining supply chain.
Niche consultants are hard to replace due to long-term expertise and reputation.
Implementation partners help clients execute pre-decided projects.
IT services firms like TCS, Wipro, Infosys have consulting arms.
Strategy consultants like McKinsey, BCG, Bain assist C-level executives in decision-making.
They help structure problems, conduct data analysis, and shape long-term strategy.
AI can now perform data analysis much faster than human consultants.
This disruption differs from past crises like the 2008 financial crisis or 2020 pandemic.
Globalization was once a strength for consulting firms with global project networks.
McKinsey reportedly helped China design its Vision 2025 and Made in China 2025 plans.
Some lawmakers in the U.S. oppose McKinsey working on government projects.
BCG employees in Shanghai were questioned by Chinese authorities.
Consulting firms' involvement in Saudi Arabia raises geopolitical concerns.
Sustainability was a top priority for companies in 2020–2022.
By 2023–2024, sustainability dropped to 10th on corporate priority lists.
Consulting firms acquired sustainability-focused companies during 2021–2022.
Mergers and acquisitions require due diligence, traditionally handled by consultants.
Due diligence is increasingly automated using web scraping tools and chatbots.
BCG collaborates with Anthropic, Bain with OpenAI, Accenture with Microsoft.
McKinsey has made several AI-related acquisitions.
Clients may eventually bypass consultants and use AI tools directly.
key_opinions: The AI revolution could be a fundamentally different disruption compared to past crises.
Globalization may now be detrimental rather than beneficial for consulting firms.
Sustainability’s decline in priority threatens the value of past consulting investments.
AI automation makes traditional consulting roles potentially redundant.
A single employee using AI chatbots could replace a five-member consulting team.
The shift to product-based consulting is a strategic response to AI disruption.
Consulting firms are not passive; they are adapting through product development.
The future of consulting lies in subscription-based product support, not just people.
The current disruption may threaten the greatness of McKinsey, BCG, and Bain.
It remains uncertain whether this disruption is a genuine threat or temporary volatility.
Clients may prefer direct access to Silicon Valley AI tools over traditional consulting.
The era of high-cost, large-consultant teams may be ending.
Geopolitical tensions are undermining the credibility of global consulting networks.
The collapse of sustainability as a priority undermines prior consulting investments.
AI adoption by clients reduces the need for external strategic guidance.
key_datapoints: McKinsey has a presence across the globe, including in Indonesia.
Deloitte operates in 150 countries.
Sustainability dropped to 10th place on corporate priority lists by 2023–2024.
AI tools are automating due diligence processes via web scraping and chatbots.
Bain collaborates with OpenAI.
BCG collaborates with Anthropic.
Accenture collaborates with Microsoft.
McKinsey has made multiple AI-related acquisitions.
A five-member consulting team could be replaced by one person using AI tools.
Product-based consulting models involve subscription fees for deployed tools.
Consulting firms are implementing layoffs amid AI-driven disruption.
Clients may reduce reliance on consultants as AI tools become more accessible.
Historical disruptions like 2008 and 2020 were overcome more strongly than this one.
AI can perform data analysis 'way way quickly' compared to human-led processes.
The shift from service-based to product-based consulting is accelerating.

to make sure there is human in um the third one is as we learned some of these things there are not technical ways where you can fine-tune the model and put the constraints that if it is um before it starts sharing some of the numbers Etc you can constrain either the data ranges or you can constrain the outliers and you can start putting that as constraints into the model now for that you need usage right you need a number of times to identify that outlier so we can fine-tune it right and put it back into the model so there are some ways that we can fine- tune each of those individual gpts to do this the right way yeah and then the last one I would say also is um each of the software vendors that are putting these tools out there they're learning all this right and they're putting in um constraints into their models and Sanity checks right that where you are you can you can dial in specific weights right in the models Etc as they are getting feedback from the users and what we're seeing from them what's coming is starting to be much more accurate and with with fewer hallucinations right so those are that it's a bundle of all of those things I would say this is an easier conversation a year from now because I do believe that a lot of the models that will be provided as parts of co-pilots Etc we'll have a lot of this already embedded in them as they have it now we're in the moment in between where we need to do a number of interventions ourselves very good so what's the process that BCG go through to decide where to apply AI so is this do you have a a governance system in place and certain review panels that make sure that any AI implement mentation is actually the the most important one aligned to your strategy or do you take an approach where you say actually let's give everyone access to AI let's give everyone access to to experimenting with it um and then people decide by themselves how to use it so I'd love to understand is there a strategic process you go through in some governance or do you make just generic tools available to everyone and and are happy for them to use them as they see fit yeah so it's both um uh with uh and what we've learned through time also by supporting a number of clients right is there will be interesting new applications that of of the AI that you cannot derive top down right but someone in the field will and then we need to make quickly we have to have ability to quickly then swarm those and help them scale it up right to the others uh but at the same time if you just wait for everything round up there might be some big important um workflows that could benefit from it but they require top down Focus so um short ansers we've done both and then specifically um on the piece around the workflows we want to focus on we've um appointed one of our most senior um Partners to run a task force uh where we've identified and we've we've had the task force focus on on two groups one is internal support functions right so HR Finance reporting um it Etc and derive what are the biggest unlocks or frictions or use cases that AI can help um turbocharge or do in a different way and then in parallel we've done the same exercise by looking at all of our different Consulting cohorts and looking at their typical workflows and then identifying where they're spending the most time and then figuring out how can we deploy AI so in the latter one um like we got down to okay um typical consultant spends 50% of his or her time writing slides and then 30% of the time um doing research um online and then you know 10% of the time writing emails and then 10% of the time in meetings if I go to most senior people it's actually the inverse right they spend almost no time writing slides they spend very they spend some time writing emails but they spend 60 70% of the time in the meetings right and so pretty much for every Cort then you go to Engineers Etc we chunked up their daily hours right and um we saw where the time is being spent and where they have frictions and then what we did was we looked at what are the tools available for any one of those steps so there's got to be tools for writing slides in a better way if you write few prompts so we found some we also said they're not having the right protections that we need so we said we're going to build a version of our own which we did we call it Dexter which now with few prompts you get a first draft of a slide Within seconds which sometimes it could have taken you hours to get to that so we've identified where the frictions or bottom legs are to eliminate them that's one two we've also looked at where we could get to the differentiated point of view so let's say you have um experts in biofarm R&D that have their body of knowledge and are pulling in on it we said boy there could be intra you know cross disciplinary insights if we could embed into those workflows data sets from elsewhere so we identified few of those workflows where we created some tools that allow them to access data they usually wouldn't right to derive a better Insight so that's on the Consulting side and then on the internal side we looked at functions like uh you know on the HR side if most of the requests coming in around the benefits like does my insurance cover this or that and we have um folks that need to wait to get that answer we can do a lot of that with ch GPT right or one of the gpts that allow you to interact quicker to get to the information and all of this in the spirit we are high growth company so the only way we can keep growing right in a sustainable way is if we start putting these um these tools um uh to to to help us we call it eliminate um uh eliminate toil and increase Joy uh so that we can focus on things that matter so hopefully these examples made sense and team is still there they meet regularly on a weekly basis we report out to the to the executive committee uh once once every every two months on the progress so it's all the way through to the CEO um on a regular basis so how do you envisage Ai and in particular generative AI changing the future of the Consulting industry um how do you see this evolving over the next 10 years oh it's so hard like a year ago we would not even have this conversation right so it's hard for me to tell you for 10 years how it's going to be out there right um I do think it's going to change how we do things I think it's going to and I know that's super high level I do think that uh probably 50% of the things we're doing today right as a task we're not going to have to do as a task right that will be done through our clever set of prompts Etc I I do think that um it will evolve us more in to the change management um uh set of conversations for example um it's not going to happen just to us right it's going to happen to our clients as well and we've built a wonderful tool for our client's sales organization and they were using it but they were not acting on what was coming out of it right and then we sat down with them and asked why not and they said well my quarterly quota is based on a totally different set of uh actions so this is helpful but I'm still going to do what I'm paid to do and we said great we're going to change your quotas or like work with your leadership to change your quotas I said that's great but not this quarter because I still have the numbers I got to hit so great well let's talk about next quarter then we talk with the leadership and they said fully agree we should do that but not this year we should do next year because my bonus is based on this year's numbers you can do it mid Midway so how do Drive change an adoption of something that you know is the right answer it's truly taking performance to the next level but the internal setup is not there or we have an examp example with a client where we took one process from 10 days to 2 minutes 10 days to two minutes um but the outcome is still 10 days and why well because the team that reviews that meets only once every 10 days and so the only way you change it is they now need to meet daily but they cannot so there's going to be a lot of like focus of the Consultants will move into driving the change in the workflows and figuring out clever ways how to rewire how we do things so that's how I see it evolving in the in the coming years very good so what pieces of advice would you give any CEO listening in here thinking I would like to do what BCG has done successfully in terms of applying AI across um their own organization how do they go about it what are some of the mistakes they need to watch out for yeah I would say learning a few things don't don't shy away from it and don't wait right and activate the the organization um what I see too many of them do is either well let's see how this all plays out and then I'll just pick a tool um issue with that is even if you wait and there is a tool that hallucinates less and it's more relevant Etc you still have the ethical questions you still have the questions on do we have the right data what's the governance process for all of this all of that takes six to 12 months so you can wait for the tool you will still need to do that part so the sooner you start it starts helping you deal with friction for example the the team asked me to build a digital version of me a digital Avatar um and like I said sure let's do it not because I want to have that but because I knew it's going to prompt bunch of questions with legal team with compliance team with risk team so I just put by saying yes a set of workflows in motion that now over three weeks I have a contract that says how my digital identity is protected um I have a team that knows how to review this a legal team knows how to deal with these questions um but that took a few weeks to get to it but now if any of my peers wants to do it it's like Snap and we can move right so the longer you punt a lot of these things you you're not eliminating that work so get started to start figuring out those frictions and what you need to put in terms of the operating model and then two um engage the organization right uh do not Outsource all of this right ourselves and others can help you get moving so when you're looking at a a third party to help you find find someone who wants to help you build capability internally because you need to rewire the business right it's part of DNA now it's not a one-time project so don't think about just Outsourcing it and hoping this goes away or that you're just going to buy a license and you're done right but find partners that can help you be player coaches to teach you give you the drum beat get you moving and then help you build the capability along the way so those would be few thoughts very good piece of advice thank you so much vad I I could carry on talking to you for hours this is super fascinating um I will have another conversation with BCG about another project more specifically um which I'm looking forward to for anyone who ever wants to rewatch this conversation or many other similar conversations on the future of Business and Technology simply head to my YouTube channel so thank you very much Vlad thank you Bernard it was nice to meet you and looking forward to continuing these conversations likewise

metadata.title: The Amazing Ways Global Consulting Firm BCG Uses AI Internally
metadata.author: Bernard Marr

key_facts: BCG has rolled out Enterprise GPT to all employees globally.
All data used in BCG's Enterprise GPT remains under internal control.
Project-specific AI conversations and IP are restricted to team members only.
Over 2,500 custom GPTs have been built by BCG consultants for specific engagements.
Custom GPTs at BCG are used for document summaries and public research analysis.
Administrative GPTs help consultants quickly generate time sheet reports from calendar data.
A consultant previously spent two weeks transcribing and analyzing 30 interviews.
A newer consultant completed the same task in three days using Enterprise GPT.
Enterprise GPT enabled rapid transcription, insight distillation, and slide generation.
The speed increase allows earlier engagement with insights and deeper follow-up analysis.
BCG conducted a controlled experiment with 750 consultants using generative AI.
Junior consultants saw productivity increases of 30–40% on straightforward tasks.
Experienced consultants saw productivity gains of 20–30% on routine tasks.
On complex tasks involving math or derivation, junior productivity dropped by 340%.
Complex tasks led to increased debugging time due to hallucinated or inaccurate outputs.
Human experts are required to validate AI outputs, especially when anomalies appear.
AI-generated predictions may reflect rare historical outliers, not just average trends.
BCG uses human-in-the-loop review to assess and correct AI-generated anomalies.
Model fine-tuning is applied after identifying consistent outlier patterns.
Vendor-level constraints and safety checks are being integrated into AI tools over time.
BCG created Dexter, an internal tool that generates first draft slides in seconds.
Dexter was developed because existing tools lacked proper data protection controls.
Consultants spend 50% of their time writing slides and 30% doing online research.
Senior consultants spend 60–70% of their time in meetings, not writing slides.
BCG’s AI strategy includes both top-down governance and bottom-up innovation.
A senior partner leads a task force focused on high-impact workflows across functions.
Internal support functions like HR and finance are prioritized for AI optimization.
Cross-disciplinary insights are enabled by embedding external datasets into expert workflows.
BCG aims to eliminate toil and increase joy through AI adoption.
Progress is reported to the executive committee every two months.
key_opinions: Generative AI acts as a superpower that accelerates insight delivery and decision-making.
AI should be viewed as a thought partner, not a fully autonomous workflow engine.
The future of consulting will shift toward change management and workflow redesign.
Speed gains from AI enable deeper exploration than previously possible.
Without intentional design, AI can reduce productivity on complex analytical tasks.
Sanity checking AI outputs is a critical skill for all consultants moving forward.
Prompt engineering is a core competency that must be taught to junior staff.
Organizations must avoid waiting for perfect tools—early action reveals operational friction.
Outsourcing AI implementation risks failing to build internal capability and ownership.
AI adoption requires co-pilots who teach and coach rather than simply deliver tools.
Leadership alignment is essential for driving behavioral and structural change.
Performance metrics must evolve alongside AI adoption to incentivize new behaviors.
Digital avatars and identity tools require early legal and compliance planning.
Top-down AI initiatives must be balanced with grassroots innovation to scale effectively.
The most valuable AI use cases emerge from real-world field challenges, not just strategy decks.
key_datapoints: 750 consultants participated in BCG’s generative AI performance experiment.
Junior consultant productivity increased by 30–40% on simple tasks with AI.
Experienced consultant productivity increased by 20–30% on routine tasks.
Junior productivity dropped by 340% on complex mathematical or analytical tasks.
One interview analysis process reduced from two weeks to three days using AI.
BCG has developed over 2,500 custom GPTs for client and project-specific use.
Typical consultant spends 50% of time writing slides and 30% on research.
Senior consultants spend 60–70% of time in meetings, not on slide creation.
Dexter generates first draft slides in seconds, replacing hours of manual work.
AI-driven market prediction was accurate 90% of the time but missed 10% of outlier events.
BCG reports progress to the executive committee every two months.
Legal and compliance workflows were initiated within three weeks of digital avatar request.
AI tools were tested against control groups using identical task sets.
AI output accuracy improved after multiple iterations and expert validation.
Model fine-tuning requires repeated exposure to outlier cases to identify patterns.

换句话说，在一个提示语中 任务是必须的， 语境和示范是重要的 而人设、格式和语气则是锦上添花 当你在写提示语的时候 在心里过一遍这个清单 这个公式可以提醒你 写提示语要 涵盖适量的相关信息 而且在下一章节你会发现 并非所有优秀的提示语 都必须用到全部六个要素 那么现在我们就用例子来单独解析每个元素 首先从任务开始 大原则是 任务句必须用动词来开头 比如生成，给，写，分析，等等 并清楚地说明你的最终目标是什么 我们可以写一个很简单的任务 比如生成一个为期3个月的训练计划 或者复杂的3步骤任务， 包括分析几百条用户反馈 分享3条最重要的见解 并且根据后续跟进的团队来 给用户反馈进行分类 第二个元素，语境 这是最棘手的一个问题 因为技术上讲，你能提供的信息无穷无尽 后来我发现，问自己这三个问题 非常有助于 给ChatGPT提供刚好足够的信息 来产生高质量的输出 首先，用户的背景是什么 其次，成功看起来是怎么样的 第三，他们所处的环境是什么 说回那个锻炼的例子，现在我可以这么写 我是一名体重70公斤的男性 我的目标是在未来3个月内 增肌5公斤 我一周只能去2次健身房，每次1小时 给我生成一个为期3个月的训练计划 我还有没有 其他背景信息呢，当然有啊 只练那些方便让我 在网上发帅气自拍所需要的肌肉 不过保证高效使用ChatGPT和Bard的关键在于 给它们提供恰好足够的信息 去管理无尽的选择 对了，虽然本期视频没有赞助商 但是各位可以通过 付费订阅我的 谷歌办公生产力技巧文章来支持我 前往下方链接了解更多 下一个讲讲示范 其实也就是举例的意思 基本上所有关于大语言模型 的研究都表明 在提示语中包含示例 能够极大的 提升输出质量 举个简单的例子 这是从一份简历上摘取的一段粗劣内容 现在我们让ChatGPT用这个框架 重写这段简历 我通过做X事项，以Y来衡量其结果，最终影响为Z 这其实就是写简历最好的办法 所以你们写简历就得这么写 比如，我给护士教授新的治疗协议 将住院死亡率降低了10% 相当于每年救助200个生命 这里有一个相对复杂一些的 针对求职面试的例子 根据我的简历 使用STAR模型 给“你最大的弱点”这一问题写一段回答 包含S情况，T任务，A行动，R结果 在这个例子中，我们不用 给一大段面试问题回答 这有点过了 而用STAR框架就能让ChatGPT 很好地进行模仿。最后一个例子 比如你要写一段岗位描述 在开头你给出一些情境描述 然后让ChatGPT参考 一段现成的岗位描述来写 比如我在领英上找到的这段岗位描述 输出的答案会模仿其格式 以及符合HR口吻的专业语言表达 这给我节省了很多时间 这里有个关键的思考 并不是每一个提示语都必须写示范 但是如果你加上一个相关的例子或者框架 能够大大提升你提示语的质量 下一个，人设 就是你希望ChatGPT或Bard 扮演的角色。专业技巧 你要想象你现在立刻想接触到的 能帮助你解决某个问题的人 如果你在锻炼时受伤了 那么这个人可能是一个康复治疗师 他有多年帮助 运动员康复的经验 如果你是一名求职者 那个人可能是一位招聘人员 如果你在传播创意方案， 那么那个人可能是一位非常擅长讲故事的 资深产品营销经理。专业技巧 你也可以指定具体某个人 但我发现只有当这个人足够出名的时候 结果才会比较好，比如沃伦·巴菲特 史蒂夫·乔布斯，以及杰夫我本人 对了我真的很想讲下这个事 就是我们线下有一个超级英雄主题的团队 我让ChatGPT给我以蝙蝠侠身份 写一封邮件，它甚至写了 “请传达给Alfred（蝙蝠侠朋友）”之类的话 落款竟然还是“你的黑暗骑士” 所以科幻角色也是可以的 反正我是会用的 第五个元素是格式，专业技巧 闭上眼睛，让你最终想获得的东西 可视化地展现在你脑海里 我那张肌肉照 要收到一百万个赞 Tmd，竟然没有。说回那个用户反馈的例子 我不想逐句念 所以我让ChatGPT 消化这些反馈，并输出一个3列的表 分别是用户反馈原文 后续负责跟进的团队 以及优先级。现在我就可以直接复制这个表 黏贴到我的Google表单里 按优先级排序，并可筛选跟进团队 其他的格式包括邮件 圆点符号清单，以及代码块 但我作为一个全职打工人 我觉得最有用的是 段落和标记文本。比如 总监刚给我发了一段很长的行业报告 首先给我提供3条关键洞察 然后写一段文章摘要 以h2作为每部分的标题样式。报告如下 专业技巧，每当我让ChatGPT 去读任何文件时 我会要求它加粗改动的内容 这样被改动的部分就一目了然 让我们快速说一下 最后的一个元素，就是语气 之后我们整合所有元素来讲一个案例 好消息是，语气是很好理解的 用随意的或正式的语气 或写一段机灵鬼怪的回答，或展示热情 或悲观的 但坏消息是 通常情况下 修饰词到用时方恨少 所以我给大家分享一个专业技巧，告诉ChatGPT 你要找的那个感觉。比如 我要给一个我没接触过的团队写一封邮件 我希望得到他们的重视 同时我又不想显得拘谨和尴尬 你能给我提供5个以上的语气关键词 以便我用来写一段ChatGPT提示语 你看，现在我可以在提示语中写 用清晰简洁的语言 写一段态度友好而自信的邮件 把所有元素整合起来 来一起看下这个完整的提示语 你是苹果公司的一名 高级产品营销经理 这是人设，你刚刚公开了 苹果和特斯拉合作的新产品 苹果汽车，你收到了一万两千个预售订单 比预期高出200%，这是语境 写一封邮件给你的老板 蒂姆·曲奇， 告诉他这个好消息 这就是任务和格式 邮件需要包含一个摘要 项目背景 解释为什么会做出这个产品 业务成绩，加上量化指标 然后以一段 感谢产品和工程团队的话作为结尾 结构示范。用清晰简洁的语言 自信友好的语气来写邮件 这是语气。注意，如果我有一份现成邮件 作为参考，我可以删掉 关于结构的指令 然后直接告诉ChatGPT 照搬我下方提供邮件的格式 然后黏贴你之前找到的邮件 然后你可以比较一下这个提示语 和更简单的提示语产生的两个结果的差异 我刚发布了新产品苹果汽车 我收到了一万两千个预售订单 请给我的老板写一封邮件 来汇报此事。这两个邮件 在具体度、可用性上都 有巨大的差异。现在你清楚了 提示语的基础技巧 我的下一个视频会让你从入门到精通 所以一定要订阅我的频道，不要错过 快去看看我的 ChatGPT工作效率视频吧 我们下期视频再见，与此同时 祝你度过美好的一天

metadata.title: Master the Perfect ChatGPT Prompt Formula (in just 8 minutes)!
metadata.author: Jeff Su

key_facts: 提示语公式包含任务、语境、示范、人设、格式和语气六个基本元素
任务是提示语中必须存在的核心要素
语境和示范对输出质量有重要影响
人设、格式和语气属于锦上添花的可选要素
任务句应以动词开头，如生成、写、分析等
用户背景、成功标准和所处环境是构建语境的关键问题
示范通过提供具体例子或框架提升输出质量
STAR模型可用于求职面试回答的结构化生成
指定知名人物角色可提高人设效果，如沃伦·巴菲特、史蒂夫·乔布斯
科幻角色如蝙蝠侠也可作为有效人设使用
格式要求可视化最终输出形态，便于直接使用
3列表格格式适用于用户反馈分类处理
段落和标记文本是全职打工人最常用的格式类型
加粗改动内容可增强文档修改可见性
语气需明确表达期望的情感风格
清晰简洁、自信友好的语气适合跨团队沟通
完整提示语整合了所有六大元素
苹果汽车预售订单达12000份，超出预期200%
提示语中加入结构示范可替代冗长指令
简单提示语与完整提示语在输出可用性上存在显著差异
该视频分享了用于提升AI提示语质量的系统性方法论
作者杰夫就职于科技行业，拥有数百小时提示工程学习经验
视频强调提示语设计需兼顾信息量与效率
key_opinions: 任务的重要性高于语境，因仅任务仍可产生有意义输出
提供恰好足够的信息能有效管理无尽选择
并非所有优秀提示语都必须包含全部六个要素
示范能极大提升大语言模型的输出质量
指定具体知名人物角色比泛化人设更有效
科幻角色扮演在实际应用中具有可行性
格式设计应基于最终输出的视觉化想象
段落和标记文本是最实用的格式类型
加粗改动内容是提高文档可读性的有效技巧
语气关键词的选择对沟通效果至关重要
清晰简洁且态度友好的语气有助于建立专业形象
完整提示语相比简化版本在实用性上优势明显
提示语公式可实现“屡试不爽”的高质量输出
提示工程是掌握ChatGPT和Google Bard的核心技能
视频内容值得订阅以获取进阶技巧
key_datapoints: 体重70公斤的男性
3个月训练计划目标为增肌5公斤
每周仅能去健身房2次，每次1小时
苹果汽车预售订单数量为12000份
预售订单比预期高出200%
每年救助200个生命（基于死亡率降低10%）
任务句必须以动词开头，如生成、写、分析等
提示语中包含示例可显著提升输出质量
建议使用STAR模型进行面试回答结构化
3列表格包括：用户反馈原文、跟进团队、优先级
总监发送的行业报告需提取3条关键洞察
报告摘要需使用h2标题样式分段
提示语中可要求加粗改动内容
语气关键词不少于5个以辅助描述情感风格
完整提示语整合6个元素，对比简单提示语效果更优
视频中提到的提示语公式已验证可重复使用
作者花费数百小时学习提示工程并应用于日常
视频未获得赞助商支持
订阅链接用于支持作者的谷歌办公生产力文章

metadata.title: Google's 9 Hour AI Prompt Engineering Course In 20 Minutes
metadata.author: Tina Huang

key_facts: Prompting is the process of providing specific instructions to a generative tool to achieve a desired outcome.
The Google Prompting Essentials course has four modules covering prompt design, everyday tasks, data analysis, and creative partnerships.
Module one focuses on crafting prompts using a five-step framework: task, context, references, evaluate, and iterate.
The five-step prompting framework is referred to as 'Tiny crabs ride enormous iguanas' for memorability.
A Persona in prompting defines the role the AI should embody, such as an anime expert.
Adding output format (e.g., table) improves structure and clarity of AI-generated results.
More context leads to more targeted and accurate AI outputs.
References help clarify intent by providing examples the AI can emulate.
Evaluation involves checking whether the AI output matches the desired result.
Iterating is a circular process that refines prompts through repeated adjustments.
The four iteration methods are revisiting the framework, breaking prompts into shorter sentences, changing phrasing, and adding constraints.
Multimodal prompting allows input/output via text, images, audio, video, and code.
Gemini supports multimodal interactions including image-based social media posts.
Hallucinations occur when AI generates incorrect or nonsensical information.
An example of hallucination: AI claims there are two hours in 'strawberry'.
AI models inherit human biases related to gender and race from training data.
The 'human-in-the-loop' approach requires verifying AI outputs for accuracy.
Module two provides use cases for emails, brainstorming, tables, and document summarization.
A gym manager can generate a staff email about schedule changes using AI.
For important writing, specify tone like 'friendly and easy to understand' instead of vague terms.
Straighterline offers affordable online courses with transferable college credits.
Over 3,000 colleges accept credit from Straighterline courses.
Module three covers data analysis and PowerPoint presentation creation.
Sensitive company data should not be input into public AI models due to privacy risks.
AI can calculate average sales per customer in a spreadsheet dataset.
AI identified no clear correlation between items available and store sales.
Module four introduces advanced techniques: prompt chaining, Chain of Thought, and Tree of Thought.
Prompt chaining links multiple prompts to build complex outputs step-by-step.
Chain of Thought prompting asks AI to explain reasoning step-by-step.
Tree of Thought prompting explores multiple reasoning paths simultaneously.
Meta prompting uses AI to generate better prompts when stuck.
An AI agent is a specialized assistant designed for specific tasks.
Agent Sim is a simulation agent for role-playing interviews.
Agent X provides expert feedback on user inputs like pitch presentations.
Creating an AI agent requires defining Persona, context, interaction type, stop phrase, and feedback mechanism.
Stop phrases can be any custom trigger, such as 'jazz hands'.
The course recommends using Google AI Studio for long-context tasks like full manuscript analysis.
key_opinions: The Google Prompting Essentials course is denser and offers better value than other Google courses like AI Essentials.
Module four is particularly impressive and packed with advanced content.
The pneumonic 'Tiny crabs ride enormous iguanas' is more memorable than the official one.
Breaking prompts into shorter sentences makes them easier for AI to process.
Switching to an analogous task often produces more engaging results.
Constraints improve focus and quality of AI-generated outputs.
The 'ramen saves tragic idiots' pneumonic helps remember the four iteration methods.
Multimodal prompting enhances creativity but requires clearer specification.
AI agents are powerful tools when properly designed.
Using AI for content creation saves significant time, especially for repetitive emails.
The course's assessment at the end aids retention through immediate review.
The instructor finds the agent creation guidelines highly practical.
Meta prompting is a valuable pro tip for overcoming prompt blocks.
The course’s emphasis on responsible AI use is essential.
The instructor personally benefits from using AI to create their own prompt library.
key_datapoints: The course takes 9 hours to complete, but this summary saves that time.
The five-step framework includes task, context, references, evaluate, and iterate.
The birthday gift example includes a friend turning 29 years old.
Favorite animes mentioned: Shangula Frontier, Solo Leveling, Naruto.

Study mode turns GPT5 into personalized tutor that adapts to your learning style and knowledge gaps. I need to learn digital marketing fundamentals for my business, but I'm a visual learner who learns best through practical examples. Create a personalized learning path. Start with a knowledge assessment to identify what I already know. Then create lessons that build systematically. Use real business case studies include practical exercises I can implement and check my understanding before moving to the next concept. Begin with the assessment. This approach creates a customized educational experience rather than just dumping information. GBT5 becomes a learning partner that adapts to your needs and pace. Prompt 17, advanced data analysis. Here's where GBT5's analytical capabilities really shine. Most people upload spreadsheets and ask for basic summaries, but experts know how to extract strategic insights. I'm uploading six months of sales data for my e-commerce business, perform a comprehensive analysis, identify seasonal trends, calculate customer lifetime value patterns, analyze product performance correlations, detect any anomalies or unusual patterns, and predict likely outcomes for the next quarter. Present findings as an executive summary with visual recommendations for strategic decisions. This transforms raw data into actionable business intelligence. GPT5 doesn't just read your data, becomes a data scientist that can spot patterns and provide strategic recommendations. Prompt 18, creative combination mastery. This is where things get really interesting. You can combine multiple creative elements in ways that would be impossible with traditional tools. Create a marketing campaign that combines the storytelling approach of Pixar movies with the direct response techniques of old school mail order ads targeted at millennial entrepreneurs who are building their first businesses. The campaign should feel emotionally compelling but drive immediate action. include three different touch points, an email sequence, social media content, and a landing page concept. This type of creative hybridization allows you to create truly unique approaches by combining elements that wouldn't normally go together. Prompt 19, template creation systems. Instead of just getting one-off outputs, experts create reusable systems and templates that can be applied repeatedly. Create a comprehensive template system for client onboarding in my web design business. include initial client questionnaire with strategic questions, project timeline template that can be customized, communication templates for each project phase, and a final delivery checklist. Make each template professional but personalized to my brand voice. Also create instructions for how to customize these templates for different client types. This approach builds business systems rather than just solving immediate problems. You're creating assets that improve your business operations long term. Prompt 20, handling complex problems. Expert level prompting involves knowing how to structure complex multi-layered problems that require sophisticated reasoning. I'm dealing with a complex business situation. My main client wants to reduce their budget by 40% but they also want to expand the scope of work. I have three team members whose jobs might be at risk and I'm considering pivoting to a different service model entirely. Help me think through this systematically. First map out all the interconnected factors and potential consequences. then generate multiple solution paths, evaluate each path's risks and benefits, and finally recommend a decision framework I can use to choose the best approach. This type of prompt treats GBT5 as a strategic thinking partner rather than just an information provider. You're leveraging its reason and capabilities to work through complex ambiguous situations. Prompt 21, master integration prompt. This is the culmination, a prompt that combines multiple advanced techniques to solve comprehensive business challenges. I am the founder of growing digital marketing agency. I need a complete strategic plan that addresses multiple interconnected challenges. Act as my senior business advisor and work through this systematically. This technique actually reminds me of something we teach inside AI Master Pro. the idea that AI works best when you give it specific roles and constraints. We have entire modules on this in our generative AI course. But the key principle is what we're doing right here. Phase one, analyze my current situation using the data I'll provide about revenue, team structure, and client portfolio. Identify strengths, weaknesses, and market position. Phase two, research market trends in digital marketing and identify emerging opportunities that align with my company's capabilities. Phase three, develop three distinct growth scenarios, conservative, moderate, and aggressive with specific tactics, resource requirements, and timeline for each. Phase four, create implementation templates, including hiring plans, service offerings, pricing strategies, and client acquisition systems. Phase five, build monitoring system with KPIs and decision points for each growth phase. Work through each phase methodically, ask clarifying questions when needed, and present deliverables that I can implement immediately. Begin with phase one, and wait for my input before proceeding. This type of master prompt demonstrates how GBT5 can serve as a comprehensive business partner rather than just a tool for individual tasks. Let me share the most important insights I've learned from working with GBT5 at this level. First, the biggest mistake I see people make is trying to get everything in one prompt. ChatGpt works best when you treat it as conversation partner rather than search engine. Build complexity through iteration rather than trying to create the perfect prompt up front. Second, always be specific about what you don't want. Chad GPT has a tendency toward explain cliches and generic responses. Explicitly telling it what to avoid is often more powerful than telling it what to include. Third, context is everything, but too much context can be counterproductive. The sweet spot is giving chat GPT enough information to understand your situation without overwhelming it with irrelevant details. Fourth, save your best prompt. When you find something that works well, document it and create variations. Build your own library of proven prompts rather than starting from scratch each time. So, three immediate steps. First, I recommend you to pick three prompts from today's video and use them this week. Learning is not just watching, it's actually implementing knowledge into your work or business. Second, build your own template library for your most common tasks. And third, if you're serious about AMy, check out AM Mastery Pro. Links in the description. Remember, the goal isn't to replace your thinking, it's to amplify it. Thanks for watching. I'll see you in the next one.

yt_req4.transcript:
AI는 나쁜 소프트웨어지만 좋은 사람이라고 농담하곤 하죠. 제 친한 친구가 건설 사업에 도움이 될 도구를 개발하려고 했어요. ChatGPT에 도움을 청했죠. 물론 ChatGPT는 이 문제를 함께 해결하고 계획을 세우자고 했죠. 그러다 ChatGPT가 며칠 뒤에 다시 와서 같이 해결하자고 했습니다. 친구가 그러더군요. ChatGPT가 며칠 뒤에 다시 오라고 하는 게 정상인가요? 사람들한테 늘 듣는 얘기라 그냥 웃기 시작했어요. 사람들은 AI를 통해 듣습니다. '15분 후에 다시 확인하세요.' AI가 그렇게 말하면 '못 한다'고 말하기 싫은 거예요. 대형 언어 모델은 특정 방식으로 행동하도록 지시받았지만, 기본적인 수준에서는 AI가 도움이 되길 원한다는 걸 알아야 해요. 그래서 '예스'라고 대답하는 경향이 있죠. 의욕이 넘치고 열정적인 인턴이죠. 지칠 줄 모르고 능력도 있고 많은 일을 하겠지만 반격하는 건 잘 못해요. AI를 가장 잘 사용하는 사람은 코더가 아니라 코치예요. 조심하지 않으면 AI가 여러분을 가스라이팅할 겁니다. 안녕하세요, 저는 제레미 어틀리입니다. 지난 16년간 스탠퍼드 대학교에서 강의한 겸임 교수죠. 저는 창의성 전문가이자 실용 AI 전문가입니다. 컨텍스트 엔지니어링이죠. 안드레이 카르파티가 트위터에 올렸을 때 처음 알게 됐어요. 쇼피파이의 CEO인 토비 룻케도 언급했을 거예요. 그래서 파헤치기 시작했죠. 프롬프트 엔지니어링의 진화라고 할 수 있죠. 컨텍스트 엔지니어링은 프롬프트 엔지니어링의 확장판이에요. 기본적으로 AI가 내가 요구하는 작업을 수행하기 위해 내가 AI에게 제공해야 하는 모든 것이 무엇인지에 대한 것입니다. 간단한 예가 있습니다. '세일즈 이메일을 작성해 주세요.' 그러면 ChatGPT가 '매력적인 이메일이 있습니다' 라고 하며 즉시 작성해 줍니다. 많은 사람들이 이렇게 말하죠. '나 같지 않은 것 같다고요.' 제가 종종 하는 말이 있어요. '어떤 소리를 내는지 말해 봤냐고요?' 대부분 '아니요, 안 해 봤어요.'라고 해요. 그렇죠. 컨텍스트 엔지니어링이죠. 이렇게 생각할 수도 있어요. 어떤 소리를 내는지 말해 준다고요. '영업 이메일을 쓰라고 하면 쓸 거예요. '제가 올린 음성과 브랜드 가이드라인에 맞춰서 세일즈 메일을 작성해 주세요'라고 하면 전혀 다른 세일즈 메일이 작성되겠지만 그건 문맥의 일부일 뿐이죠? 또한 잠재 고객과의 통화 내용을 업로드해서 '브랜드 음성 가이드라인에 있는 영업용 이메일을 작성해 주세요. 이 고객과 나눈 대화를 언급하는 내용으로요'라고 요청할 수도 있습니다. 그런 다음 통화에서 언급된 제품 사양도 추가할 수 있습니다. 당신의 목표는 가능한 한 신뢰할 수 있는 출력을 내는 건데, AI는 당신의 마음을 읽을 수가 없어요. 대부분의 사람들은 저희와 함께 일하기 시작하면 컨텍스트 엔지니어링에 대해 생각하기 시작한다는 걸 깨닫죠. AI가 제 마음을 읽을 줄 알았다고들 말해요. 암묵적인 것들을 명시적으로 만들어야 해요. 컨텍스트 엔지니어링의 가장 간단한 테스트는 바로 인간성 테스트입니다. 프롬프트와 AI에게 제공하는 모든 문서를 작성한 다음 복도를 걸어가서 인간 동료에게 줍니다. 그들이 당신이 요청한 것을 할 수 없다면, AI가 못 해도 놀라지 마세요. 어떤 사람들은 예를 들어 인지 오프로딩이라는 개념에 대해 걱정합니다. 인간이 실제로 사고를 멈추거나 한 연구자의 표현에 따르면 졸음에 빠지는 관찰 현상이죠. 사람들은 지금 AI가 우리를 더 멍청하게 만드는 건 아닌지 걱정하고 있어요. 제 생각에 AI는 거울 같아요. 일을 덜어내고 싶고 게으르고 싶은 사람들에게는 도움이 될 것이고, 더 인지적으로 예리하고 비판적인 사고를 하고 싶은 사람들에게도 도움이 될 거예요. 그래서 예를 들어, 비판적 사고를 유지하거나 강화하고 싶다면 사용자 지정 지침의 일부는 다음과 같아야 합니다. '저는 비판적이고 예리한 분석적 사고를 유지하려고 노력합니다. 대화에서 기회가 있을 때마다 제 비판적 사고 능력을 북돋아 주세요.' 이제 해 볼게요. 이 모든 걸 알아야 해요. AI는 도움이 되는 조수가 되도록 프로그램되었거나, 대규모 언어 모델의 일부 버전은 특정한 방식으로 행동하도록 지시받았습니다. 기본적인 수준에서 알아야 해요. AI는 도움이 되고 싶어 합니다. 그래서 '네'라고 말하기 쉽죠. 의욕이 넘치고 열정적인 인턴은 지칠 줄 모르고 유능하며 많은 일을 하겠지만, 반격하는 데는 서툴러요. 경계를 정하는 데도 서툴죠. 그래서 조심하지 않으면 AI가 가스라이팅을 할 거예요. AI는 대부분의 인간이 솔직한 피드백을 원하지 않는다는 것을 알아요. 잘했다는 말을 듣고 싶어 하죠. 그래서 AI가 '잘했어요, 친구!'라고 칭찬해요. 그렇다고 해서 실제로 잘했다는 뜻은 아니에요. 제가 쓰는 방법은 항상 AI에게 지시하는 거죠. 냉전 시대 러시아 올림픽 심판 흉내를 잘 내 보세요. 냉혹하고 깐깐하게요. 조금이라도 움찔하면 감점해 주세요. 어려운 피드백은 감당할 수 있어요. 물론 웃기기도 해요. 그들이 말하길, '내 안의 볼셰비키를 끌어내서.' 바보 같은 말을 하면 42점이 나오거든요. 훨씬 낫죠. 이제 통찰력 있고 비판적인 관점을 갖게 됐으니까요. AI의 소프트웨어가 나쁘다고 농담하지만 좋은 사람들이에요. 좋은 사람인데 나쁜 소프트웨어를 다루고 있다는 걸 깨달으면 접근 방식이 바뀌어요. 볼륨을 요구하고 반복하고 다시 시도하고 다시 다시 고려해 보라고 요청합니다. 저는 인간의 인지 편향에 집착하는데, 놀라운 점은 제가 인간의 주요 편향을 100% 보여준다는 겁니다. 창업자로서 이미 아시겠지만 아이디어는 쉬운 부분입니다. 실제로 제품을 구축하는 실행 과정이 모든 것을 늦춥니다. 바로 이 지점에 Lovable이 필요합니다. 단순한 AI 도구가 아니라 주문형 엔지니어링 팀이죠. 아이디어를 간단히 설명하세요. Lovable은 전체 프런트엔드, 백엔드, 데이터베이스를 구축하여 코드를 작성하지 않고도 실제 프로덕션 준비 소프트웨어를 출시할 수 있게 합니다. 이미 10만 개 이상의 신제품을 지원하고 있으며, 250만 명의 개발자가 원하는 것을 설명하는 것만으로 아이디어를 소프트웨어로 바꿀 수 있도록 돕고 있습니다. 의심도, 지연도, 변명도 없습니다. 몇 달이 아니라 몇 주 만에 출시됩니다. 그런데 말이죠, 이 팀들은 여전히 작습니다. 사실 Team EO도 Lovable을 사용하여 다가오는 학교 플랫폼을 구축하고 있는데, 아주 마음에 듭니다. 비기술 창업자이거나 병목 현상 없이 구축하고 싶다면, 오늘 Lovable을 무료로 사용해 보세요. 프로모션 코드 Eo22를 사용하면 Lovable Pro 플랜을 첫 구매 시 20% 할인받을 수 있습니다. 좋은 소식은, 여러분이 인류라는 이상한 지능을 다루는 법을 배웠다면, 인공지능이라는 이상한 지능을 다루는 데 필요한 모든 것을 알게 될 거라는 겁니다. 인공지능이라는 이상한 지능 말이죠. 인지 과학자들이 오래전부터 알고 있던 것 중 하나는 인간의 문제 해결과 의사 결정이 '소리 내서 생각하기'라는 현상에 의해 향상된다는 겁니다. 실제로 인간이 자신의 문제를 소리 내서 생각하게 하면, 의사 결정이 향상되고 문제 해결이 향상됩니다. 여러분 자신에게도 해당됩니다. 아이와 함께 일하는 부모라면 그렇겠죠. 주니어 직원과 함께 일하는 관리자라면 그 문제를 어떻게 해결할지 누군가에게 소리 내서 생각하게 하는 건 사실입니다. 종종 돌파구로 이어지죠. AI의 이상한 점은 AI도 마찬가지라는 겁니다. 이것을 '사고의 연쇄 추론'이라고 합니다. AI가 소위 '소리 내서 생각하게' 하면 모델의 결과물이 의미 있게 향상됩니다. 그럼 어떻게 할까요? 어떤 기술적인 마법 같은 건 필요 없습니다. 주어진 프롬프트에 한 문장만 추가하면 됩니다. 프롬프트를 주고 다음을 말하세요. 제 질문에 답하기 전에 사고 과정을 단계별로 설명해 주세요. 이것이 사고의 연쇄 추론입니다. 왜 효과가 있을까요? 대규모 언어 모델의 기본 아키텍처로 돌아갑니다. 언어 모델이 응답을 생성할 때 일어나는 일은 다음 단어를 예측하는 겁니다. 언어 모델은 응답을 미리 계획하지 않습니다. 예를 들어 이 세일즈 이메일 작성을 도와달라고 하면 좋은 세일즈 이메일이 무엇인지 묻지 않습니다. 여기 결과물이 있습니다. 어쩌면 '철퍼덕' 하는 소리가 날 수도 있죠? 철퍼덕. 이메일이 여기 있습니다. 한 번에 한 단어씩 생각하죠? 챗GPT나 제미니 또는 다른 많은 모델을 보면 텍스트가 스크롤되는 것이 보이는데, 그건 영리한 UX 해킹이나 귀여운 디자인 결정이 아닙니다. 그것은 말 그대로 모델이 작동하는 방식입니다. 한 번에 한 단어씩 생각하지만, 중요한 것은 다음 단어를 생각할 때 프롬프트와 생성된 모든 텍스트를 활용하여 다음 단어를 생성한다는 겁니다. 그리고 다음 단어를 생각했죠. 프롬프트와 모든 텍스트, 그리고 마지막 단어를 받아서 다음 단어를 생각합니다. 예를 들어, 이메일 작성을 도와달라고 하면 모델은 거의 항상 이렇게 시작할 겁니다. metadata.title: Stanford's Practical Guide to 10x Your AI Productivity | Jeremy Utley
metadata.author: EO

key_facts: AI는 도움이 되고 싶어 하며 '네'라고 대답하는 경향이 있다.
대규모 언어 모델은 특정 방식으로 행동하도록 지시받았다.
AI는 인간의 마음을 읽을 수 없으며, 명시적인 지시가 필요하다.
컨텍스트 엔지니어링은 프롬프트 엔지니어링의 확장판이다.
사고의 연쇄 추론은 AI에게 사고 과정을 단계별로 설명하게 하는 기법이다.
소수샷 프롬프팅은 좋은 예시와 나쁜 예시를 제공하여 결과 품질을 높인다.
리버스 프롬프팅은 AI가 필요한 정보를 요청하게 만드는 기법이다.
역할 부여는 AI에게 지식의 집중 영역을 알려주는 효과가 있다.
어려운 대화를 연기하기 위해 세 개의 채팅 창을 활용할 수 있다.
성격 프로파일러, 대화 상대, 피드백 제공자 세 가지 역할을 분리하면 효과적이다.
AI는 인간의 인지 편향을 100% 반영할 수 있다.
Lovable은 아이디어를 소프트웨어로 전환할 수 있는 주문형 엔지니어링 팀이다.
Lovable은 10만 개 이상의 신제품을 지원하고 있으며, 250만 명의 개발자가 사용한다.
Lovable을 통해 몇 주 만에 실제 프로덕션 준비 소프트웨어를 출시할 수 있다.
Lovable Pro 플랜은 프로모션 코드 Eo22로 첫 구매 시 20% 할인 가능하다.
제레미 어틀리는 스탠퍼드 대학교에서 16년간 겸임 교수로 강의했다.
제레미 어틀리는 창의성 전문가이자 실용 AI 전문가이다.
컨텍스트 엔지니어링의 가장 간단한 테스트는 인간성 테스트이다.
AI는 '잘했어요, 친구!'라고 칭찬하지만, 이는 사실과 다를 수 있다.
AI는 가스라이팅을 할 수 있으며, 조심해야 한다.
사고의 연쇄 추론은 언어 모델이 한 단어씩 생각하면서 다음 단어를 예측하는 방식이다.
AI의 응답은 블랙박스이며, 사고 과정을 알면 평가가 가능하다.
사고의 연쇄 추론을 적용하면 모델이 작업의 모든 사고 과정을 포함한다.
좋은 예시와 나쁜 예시를 함께 제시하면 더 나은 결과를 얻을 수 있다.
key_opinions: AI는 거울처럼 작용하며, 게으르거나 비판적으로 사고하고 싶은 사람 모두에게 도움이 된다.
AI를 가장 잘 사용하는 사람은 코더가 아니라 코치이다.
사람들이 AI를 통해 듣는다는 것은 '15분 후에 다시 확인하세요'라는 말이 '못 한다'고 말하기 싫기 때문이라고 본다.
사고의 연쇄 추론은 기술 마법이 아니라 단순한 프롬프트 추가로 가능하다.
소수샷 프롬프팅은 형용사보다 실제 예시를 제시하는 것이 훨씬 효과적이다.
나쁜 예시를 요구하는 것은 AI의 사고 과정을 이해하는 데 유용하다.
리버스 프롬프팅은 기술 패러다임이 아닌 팀 동료 패러다임의 핵심이다.
역할 부여는 AI에게 지식 연결의 방향성을 제시한다.
다양한 제약 조건을 스스로 강요하는 것이 문제 해결에 도움이 된다.
AI는 인간의 상상력의 한계를 넘어서는 가능성을 열어준다.
노벨 경제학상 수상자 토머스 셸링의 말처럼, 자신에게 일어나지 않을 일은 상상할 수 없다.
집단적으로 다양한 개인의 상상력을 결합하면 '인접한 가능성'이 발생한다.
AI 협업의 숙달도가 높아질수록 가능한 응용 분야가 늘어난다.
이 영상에서 가장 중요한 일은 정지 버튼을 누르고 이미 놀라움을 준 무언가를 해보는 것이다.
AI는 나쁜 소프트웨어지만 좋은 사람이라는 농담이 의미 있는 접근 방식을 시사한다.
key_datapoints: Lovable은 10만 개 이상의 신제품을 지원하고 있다.
250만 명의 개발자가 Lovable을 사용하여 아이디어를 소프트웨어로 전환하고 있다.
Lovable을 통해 몇 달이 아니라 몇 주 만에 제품을 출시할 수 있다.
Lovable Pro 플랜은 프로모션 코드 Eo22로 첫 구매 시 20% 할인된다.
어려운 대화 그레이더 GPT의 평가는 100점 만점에 78점이다.
제레미 어틀리는 스탠퍼드 대학교에서 16년간 겸임 교수로 활동했다.
AI가 '15분 후에 다시 확인하세요'라고 말하는 것은 '못 한다'고 말하기 싫기 때문이다.
사고의 연쇄 추론을 적용하면 모델이 사고 과정을 단계별로 설명한다.
소수샷 프롬프팅에서 좋은 예시 5개를 제시하는 것이 권장된다.
AI는 인간의 주요 인지 편향을 100% 보여준다.
팀 EO는 Lovable을 사용하여 학교 플랫폼을 구축했다.
실제 대화에서 AI가 제공하는 피드백은 역사적으로 처음으로 대화 전에 가능해졌다.
사고의 연쇄 추론을 통해 모델이 어조, 청중, 목표, 맥락을 고려한다.
AI가 '친애하는 친구에게'라고 시작하기 전에 '존경하는 동료에게'로 바꾸는 결정이 이루어진다.
사고의 연쇄 추론을 적용하면 모델이 '철퍼덕' 소리 없이 답변을 생성한다.

yt_req5.transcript: Hey, so I've recently started working with a few AI consultants from the big four of consulting firms. If you guys are unfamiliar, that's Deote, PWC, EEY, and KPMG. They are pretty expensive. Some of the management consulting guys get up to over $300,000 a year. I'm doing this primarily for my own agency, Leftclick, to see if there's any juice that I could squeeze out of them, ways that I could price higher and so on and so forth. But also, as somebody that never went to school for any of this stuff, management consulting or otherwise, I'm interested in knowing how real consultants that work with multi-billion dollar companies and stakeholders identify and then address real business problems. So, I've learned quite a bit. And what I want to do in this video is I want to show you the key AI consulting frameworks that multi-million dollar companies are using all day long right now to reliably move the needle for their clients so that you as a AI consultant, freelancer, or agency can stop competing on price and start competing on things that actually really matter like business insight and strategy. All right, so first before I go frameworks, uh two main takeaways from working with consultants over the last few weeks. Number one, most of the principles behind AI consulting are literally just consulting. Nothing super special there. AI in these organizations is actually treated as the least important part of the AI consulting service. And the reason why is because AI hasn't actually made anything possible that was not possible before. All it has done is increase the efficiency with which you can do things. So the only real leverage is applying AI to pre-existing business flows that are already producing some measurable capital. Um it is definitely not in inventing something new with AI or applying AI to a completely new domain or business problem. Okay? And it makes sense because it's trained off of data that human beings created. So what this means for us is if you learn consulting concepts as opposed to a bunch of technical stuff, uh you will become much more adept at solving real business problems with AI. My second point is that consulting is really just thinking. So the best consultants are typically the best thinkers. Consulting, at least if you're really good at it, is basically just the science of being effective and involves a lot of pre-existing frameworks that people have been coming up with over the course of decades and hundreds of years to guide through decisions. So if you guys want to become better thinkers, we can start by taking a lot of what consulting has already done for us. They've already carved out a big chunk of the path and applying that to our own lives, whether or not it's in business. Okay. So let's actually go through the four main overarching frameworks that AI consultants are using today. The first is one of the very first things that any consultant will learn. It's called the driver tree. And in short, the driver tree is a systematic way of identifying the drivers behind a business problem. What you do is you list your goal and then you reverse engineer from your goal to find the drivers that actually move that goal forward, make it happen. Then once you do that, you can start working on the drivers themselves. You just rinse and repeat to find the things that drive the drivers. So most newbies in any sort of businessto business scenario, you know, they'll land their first client and their first client will say something like, "Hey, our ads aren't working." And because the newbies are super enthusiastic and they don't really understand how clients work, they'll take those clients at face value and then immediately start pitching solutions and building things out to, you know, improve the stated problem. But this loses the forest for the trees. Now, it will also lose you as a consultant a ton of money. and it will impair your ability to drive real business outcomes because there is a difference between a stated need and then an implicit need, a thing that somebody is not telling you. So instead, you can deliver way more value by just walking through a simple driver tree. Here's how it works. First, you define your goal in the simplest terms. So that might be growing revenue, increasing profit, uh improving retention. And I wouldn't over complicate this part. They're generally a handful of stated business goals that any client out there is looking to achieve. uh sometimes they are implicit which means you must determine them for yourself and then put them in front of them. But yeah really the only key guiding principle here is you have to be specific. You cannot just say I want to grow my business. You instead need to provide a specific metric uh an amount to grow that metric and then a time period within which to do so. So I'll give you an example. Let's say your goal is I want to double my topline revenue in the next year. We have a metric which is the revenue. We have the amount which is double and we have the time period which is the year. Okay. Second, you must identify the minimum essential drivers to achieve that goal. And ideally, you would aim for two to four major drivers. If you do any more, you're probably overthinking it or over complicating it. The way that I see things is I use AAM's Razer here, which is a thinking tool that basically says the simplest answer is probably the right one. Uh so, for example, if your goal is to double your topline revenue in the next year, you have some pretty clear drivers. I.e. the average uh relationship length is around 2 months. Well, you could focus your time, effort, and money on getting new customers for the service. And of course, that would probably improve your topline revenue to some degree. But the much more effective thing to do would be to reduce your churn, aka improve your retention. So, using this formula, you would be foregoing acquisition to focus on the retention. And while it's not always the best play, uh, in this situation, retention is just so much cheaper per unit work to move than acquisition. So, it's, you know, what I'd recommend doing. Okay, so that's the first two. The third is something you guys probably haven't thought about, which is that value equals cash flow divided by risk. Now, this is a valuation mindset instead of a usual accounting one. Probably is not going to mean a lot to people here. So, um, you know, we all come from a services background. Let me run you through this. The higher the cash flow and the lower the risk, the more money a business is worth, aka the higher the valuation. So, a concrete example is if you had two SAS companies, both are in similar industries, and they both make $100,000 a month in recurring revenue. Let's say company A has a bunch of very predictable enterprise clients, and they have longer contract lengths, you know, maybe two years or so, whereas company B tends to work with small to mid-size businesses, uh, and then they're all on a month-to-month contract instead. If you think about it, company A working with a two-year, you know, enterprise cycles, uh, which are typically more stable and less likely to change vendors. Company A is going to be worth significantly more than company B simply by virtue of the fact that it has lower risk. And if you look at our equation, because the risk is lower, the total valuation of the business is going to be higher. Now, when you're pitching systems, something to keep in mind, specifically with automation that not a lot of people talk about is that risk. Sometimes AI systems increase risk. So even if they do increase cash flow, if the increase in risk offsets the increase in business value and revenue, sometimes this isn't actually worth it. Now obviously this is a you know nuanced thing. You are happy to increase cash flow in certain situations. It does mean you increase risk and I do it all the time. But in other instances um you know it does the exact opposite. So sometimes you will automate a process that used to be up to a bunch of people and the people didn't do a very good job and thus the performance is pretty variable in output and then because you're automating you'll actually decrease the risk. And so those are the situations that you want to go for as somebody that is selling AI services or automating business processes. Right? If you can find a golden goose scenario where you both increase cash flow but also decrease risk, what you're doing is you're basically multiplying that equation out many many more times and improving the total value of the decision significantly. Another real example from maker school was a guy called Nick. Very handsome fellow, I'm sure. He was working with a real estate coaching client who wanted an AI chatbot. uh the stated need there was you know they wanted to build out some sort of intelligent visibility dashboard and he was convinced that the problem was that he didn't have enough advanced AI in his business that the AI needed to be smarter which is obviously a relatively unsophisticated belief but Nick drilled down further when he thought about in the context of business acumen so the things that we just talked about profit equals revenue minus costs growth equals acquisition plus retention plus expansion Nick found that the real issue was not the quality of the AI at all it was the client's churn essentially the client's turn was just way too high, which made all of this unjustifiable to begin with. So instead of building an AI system or spending a bunch of time chasing money and and marginal returns, Nick built a churn prevention system, essentially AI personalized onboarding sequences, a proactive 7-day and 30-day success check-in, and then a few triggers that would flag when clients said things like, "Hey, this feels overwhelming." before they canceled. And these simple things, despite not being what the client asked for, significantly improved the bottom line and ultimately amount to the project being a success. So what the client thought they needed was AI. What the client really needed was less churn. The way that you figure this out is through driver trees and strong business acumen to build your models with. So before you pitch any AI solution, identify which of the three major formulas you are actually moving. Are you increasing revenue? Are you decreasing costs? Are you improving acquisition or retention or expansion? Are you decreasing or increasing risk? Right? And you can do multiple of these at the same time. In fact, most usually do. But you'll find that there is one major thing that a system will do uh over others. And if you can't answer any of those questions clearly, in reality, your client probably won't be able to either, which means you probably shouldn't do the thing to begin with. Okay. So, now we understand how to diagnose problems that are high leverage using the principles of both driver trees and then also business acumen. But there's still two more frameworks that I want to talk about that these big four consultants uh showed me. And one of them was very interesting to me and one that I never really sat down and thought about. Uh, and it'll sound very simple, but it was basically just the principle of communication. So, you can have the best ideas in your head, but if you can't get those ideas across to a customer, doesn't matter, right? You and the customer are going to lose. So, consultants don't just spend all their time actually just building their ideas and making themselves better thinkers. They also work on becoming better communicators, which if you guys are in maker school, you guys have seen my content, is very, very important to your bottom line. So, I want to start with what I would call probably the most important communication principle I learned in consulting, which I was already doing, but I didn't fully realize, and it's called the pyramid principle. Uh, in the pyramid principle, it's very simple. You just state the conclusion first. Then you supply any supporting arguments after. Basically, you're not like burying the lead. Most people will do this backwards. They will start with a bunch of context. They'll build up a compelling story and narrative, and then finally, they will at the very bottom of the thing get to the point. uh by the time they reach the conclusion, the client has probably already come up to their own conclusion or just stopped paying attention because everybody skims nowadays. So, as a quick example of the pyramid principle, let's say my goal is to grow the revenue of maker school to 200% in the next 12 months, right? That is a driver tree style goal. If I was communicating this to myself, I would first use driver trees to determine the factors of my 200% revenue increase goal, which in this case is going to be increasing acquisition, customer transaction volume, and then lifetime value. Right? I would then write this goal. I would put it first and then I would explain how after. Uh I'm just going to pull something out of my ass here, but to grow the revenue of Maker School by 200% in 12 months. Uh we can expand who pays, how much they pay, how long they keep paying. Uh we can increase customer acquisition. We can do this through more traffic. We can do this through more ads. We can do this through more partnerships, uh more content, and then we can also increase the conversion rate on that traffic. Uh second, we can increase the average transaction value of the converted traffic, which we can do by introducing some sort of upsell, uh adding some premium tier to Maker School, adding some private one-on-one coaching, offering cross cells, uh templates, playbooks, and automation bundles. And finally, we can increase the uh customer lifetime value itself, which we can do by increasing retention through better community ties, more touch points, structured progress tracking, reducing some form of churn with, I don't know, accountability, all stuff that I am myself actually doing. But anyway, the point that I'm making is we started with the thing that we wanted to do, right? The goal and then after we stated the goal and the client bought into the goal, then we supported it with a bunch of stated actions that we are saying are likely to actually improve the goal. Okay, this is how you get buy in. Another big principle is when you are pitching a consultant always start with the problem first. So, uh, practically what that means is if you're creating a proposal for some service, like don't start with the executive abstract. You know, don't start with company whatever is a $5 million per year business in the XYZ industry that does blank. Uh, cuz nobody really cares about that. You're just wasting character space. Instead, start with the problem the customer is suffering from, right? Leftclick is currently spending $45,000 on customer acquisition and seeing next to no returns. This is crippling growth because you don't really have that much cash flow to begin with. That makes it an existential risk, right? Right? If you put that problem in front of people and if they resonate with that problem and then you support it with conclusions, people are going to be a lot more likely to like listen to you because you're not bearing the lead you're putting in front of them, but also actually like take your advice seriously and do something about it. Okay, so in a nutshell, once you are done identifying and quantifying the problem, okay, once you start with the end and then you frontload what the need is, then and only then do you actually focus on the solution. All right, the last major consulting framework is fast and it is a model not just for consulting but for better decision-making too. So, I learned this from watching those big four guys work. It is essentially a four-step process you can apply to any problem, whether it's a business problem or a personal problem to guide your thinking. Effective consulting is effective thinking. So, if you don't structure your thinking in some way, you are usually leaving some sort of outcome on the table. This will help stop that. And the way it works is the F stands for first principles. This is where you strip a problem into its fundamentals. You rebuild that from the ground up. You do not accept assumptions. uh practical example instead of you know we need to automate our invoicing process which is a solution that you are pre-imposing on the problem you know start with no prior solution just ask yourself what the hell's the problem what's the straightest line path to fixing the problem right so instead of hey we need to automate our invoicing process ask what do I want well I want to get paid faster and then you use that driver tree idea to figure out where to apply your time and your effort A stands for actionoriented so focus on what can be implemented and action in the next 24 hours not on some perfect solution which will take months or years to generate uh basically you just want to bias yourself and your organization towards doing something rather than sitting around in your ass and planning all day. So instead of you know let's research uh all the CRM options for 3 months and then make a decision you should know that like the probability of you making a good decision with no actual real world market feedback is quite low. So say something like hey why don't we pick the top two CRM today? Why don't we just like both uh run them in parallel for a week trial and then at the end of that week trial we'll decide and just move forward. It's like yeah will that be the perfect decision? probably not. But if it's like 90% of the way to a perfect decision and you do it in like onetenth of the time, that's massive leverage. S stands for second order thinking. So we got the first principles down and now we have the action down. What we need to do is basically go one step further and assuming what we're thinking of implementing works out, we need to consider the outcome beyond the immediate. So what happens if this thing works, you know, or what happens if it doesn't work? Instead of saying, "Hey, this chatbot will handle 80% of support tickets," uh, you should say, "If the chatbot handles 80% of support tickets, what the hell happens next? Are we going to be able to deal with that? And if not, how do we implement another solution to deal with the inevitable bottleneck that we're going to be creating?" And then finally, T stands for triangulation. This is really important. Once you've gone through this process of thinking through first principles, then making your stuff actionable and then considering the the second order consequences of your idea and then laying it all out in front of you, then and only then do you triangulate this information with some other data source. Why? Because in this way you are forced to think through a problem yourself first and your conclusions will not be constrained or colored or biased by somebody else's work. I see it really similarly to like doing your homework yourself first. uh you know to like learn the concepts and and so on and so forth before checking the answer book after. You would never check the answer book before if you really wanted to learn something right like because then that's just memorization. So instead you you focus on applying first principles to a problem. Focus on your own human intellect and applying that to a system then after you are done and you have some stated hypothesis with some stated solution. Then check to see what other people did. That's how you end up with novel creative solutions that win and then drive disproportionate outcomes. Okay. Okay, so here's a real example from our community. Maxi Maximillian, he's one of our members who was consulting for a client in the healthcare industry. Uh he was approached with what looked like a very simple request which was hey can you build me an AI transcription model for doctors and this is very very stereotypical fast. So thinking about it through fast first principles instead of accepting the problem as just stated he just asked hey do we actually need to build a new AI model for this? And what he quickly realized was no you don't need to build a new AI model for this. All you need to do is find a way to record audio and then just get it transcribed accurately, right? Like that's really the constraints of the problem if you just approach it from a first principles perspective. So the fundamental requirement was literally just a microphone in the room and then he needed to be able to send it off to some sort of transcription thing. Building a model was just a suggestion that the client had sent him because they did not fully understand what the technology behind that meant. Building a model is a very involved process, right? You need AI engineers. You need uh uh you know tons of data. You need like a massive massive data pipeline and just way more in the way of hardware, servers, and work than most people would ever be able to accomplish on their own. But using a pre-existing transcription model, well, that's an entirely different story. So next, actionoriented uh rather than building like some full stack app with a custom AI model, all he did was he identified a very simple test. Okay, it was basically like a pilot. Hey, can I do a voice recording? Send it to uh some pre-existing model and then get that summarized. And it was a very very tiny little MVP that you could literally implement with an hour to let the client know yes, this is possible or no, this isn't. Okay, so after that second order thinking, which is where you ask yourself, hey, if this works, what the hell happened? So assuming that he solved this problem, which he was obviously going to do. It's not a very complicated system. What happens next? Well, the company would obviously want to implement it, right? And if that occurred, what gives? Well, as we know in the medical industry, we have a lot of compliance issues. And so HIPPA compliance for instance was going to matter a lot to medical records for that business. So he went and he checked to see what were the penalties if I broke this compliance. And then he quickly realized that he needed a solution to avoid breaking the compliance which was either local models or some sort of secure infrastructure. And then finally triangulation instead of reinventing the whole wheel now he just looked to see if there were any existing tools and there ended up being some commir and caragon that were available that would already do what he was asking. So I use fast every week with my own clients at leftclick. When a client comes to me with some sort of very complex automation request, I do not immediately start mapping out their workflow. I will run it through fast, which in reality is a 5 to 10 minute process. It is not a very long or difficult thing to do. And if it makes sense, and only if it makes sense do I continue. If it doesn't, I will discuss it with the client. Now, I've used frameworks like this over the course of the last couple years to make hundreds of thousands of dollars in agency work. It is very, very straightforward to do, and I'd highly recommend thinking about every project that you take from here on out in that way. All right, so to wrap things up, here are how these four frameworks work together. First, you start with driver trees to identify what actually matters in a business. Uh business acumen then ensures that you are moving the actual right levers and that you know what it is that you are trying to do. Uh communication then gets clients to say yes to your solutions. And then fast makes everything systematic, repeatable. Then it's also a thinking tool that extends outside of just business. So I very much transitioned from just an automation builder a few years ago to a full-fledged like systems consultant. Instead of just selling AI tools, I actually help companies think through problems systematically and that is the bulk of what I get paid for. AI is just one of the many levers that I could pull. Uh and the technical implementation, while fun and enjoyable and also pretty interesting, uh is not the thing that ends up making me most the money, it is the way that I approach business problem solving. So, if you want to see how Leftclick, my company, applies this thinking to real business problems, feel free to book a call with my team. We will walk you through your specific situation using these frameworks and also show you exactly how to drive revenue, improve your margins, and reduce risk in your business. Also obligatory, if you like this sort of stuff and maybe want to start your own AI consulting outfit, definitely check out Maker School. It's my 90-day accountability program where I guarantee you your first paying customer for an AI or no code tool related service in 90 days or your money back. Thank you very much for watching. Hope you guys found this valuable and have a lovely rest of the day. Bye.
